It's JT from Bulletproof for BJJ and today we're going to be taking you guys
through our favorite pressing moves to get you stronger for BJJ.
In BJJ being able to press is super important whether you're giving
somebody a stiff arm or you're trying to stop them from taking you down or
you're just framing up from underneath side control. We need this strength. How
do we develop it? Overhead press. Now there's a lot of moves out there you could
do. People love bench press, people love pushups. The reason why we love
overhead press at Bulletproof for BJJ is as heaps of crossover. Not only is it
going to get your shoulders really strong overhead, it's going to develop really
strong triceps, very good rotator cuts and also really good core. And we have
an extra move for you today which is going to help improve your grip. Check it out
guys. Kettlebell overhead press is the best move for you to start with in your
pressing journey but we've got to get the setup right. So look at your rack
position. Make sure the kettlebell is on a 45 degree angle and so you've got a
nice neutral wrist. Also your elbows resting against your ribs. So that as you
press you're pushing all the way up and through and then also packing the
shoulder down as we draw down. What's great about this press as opposed to being
out here and working through a limited range is we get full activation
through our scap, rotator cuff, deltoid and tricep. Also make sure that when
we're doing this we're bracing our core and squeezing our glutes. So there's a
whole body movement. If you want to generate more power in your hand you've got
to get tighter in the core and the hips. So that way you have a nice strong press
and we're creating maximum strength for the movement. Kettlebell palm press is
the progression on your normal kettlebell overhead press. Let me show you how we
set that up. I'm going to fold from my rack position to my left hand. Now I
fold back to my right. I want the handle resting against my wrist. Now make sure
you pay attention because the kettlebell is far more unstable. This means as you
go to press you've got to really keep your eye on the ball. This is going to
require far more stability from your core, your shoulder and your triceps because
you cannot close the grip. This has fantastic crossover to no-gey especially when
you are pushing people away. Now I have to make sure that I'm keeping it over my
center of gravity. If I bring it too far off I'm likely to drop the kettlebell.
So keeping core tight, keeping hand close, do your best to squeeze your fingers
around and grip the kettlebell. And that is a kettlebell palm press. Kettlebell
bottoms up press. Now this is your progression from the palm press. A lot harder
on the grip. Take a look. Now when I'm setting up guys I actually roll my wrist
over just a fraction. So I've got a nice little cup for the kettlebell to sit
in. Crushing my grip, cleaning the kettlebell up. The whole time, keeping
tension in my grip and my core. Now when I press up it's super important. I pay
attention. Don't spot with your face. I'm keeping my obliques and lats tight as I
press. This is fantastic not only for your grip but for your rotator cuff. The
harder you squeeze the harder your rotator cuff works. This is a particularly
challenging exercise because what you will find is that you will fatigue quickly.
So keeping the stability the whole time is going to be a big challenge.
And that is the kettlebell bottoms up press. To get stronger with your overhead press we start
with our normal kettlebell press. Once you can do three sets of eight then we
progress to the palm press. Once you've worked on that for a while and you can do
three sets of eight with the palm press then you're ready to progress to the
bottoms up press. Spend a bit of time there it'll be challenging. Once you
can master that and get three sets of eight then you're ready to take your weight

That is 20% of your body weight for a set of eight on the bottoms up press. Now if
we're talking world class black belt standard we're looking at a set of three with
35% of your body weight. Now do the math that's tough. It's going to take a

So start at the beginning with the conventional press and work your way up to
